Seriously.  Nothing important here beyond what I'm writing for me.  If you value your time, you'll skip it.

Alright, so I'm having people continuously paint a picture of me that I think is not quite representative... I'll be fair:  I think they grab a portion of who I am, but they expand the one small part they're aware of to represent the whole of me.  I made that mistake not long ago with a friend's girlfriend, and he promptly argued with me about how it was wrong to asssume that my experience of the person represented the whole of that person.  The resentment I had for my friend because he had proved his point to me made me more aware of when this is happening to me and when I do it to others.  

It's an odd feeling when people consider you to be something that you're not... I have a few good examples of this;  People will continue to say that I'm smart.  I know better than most of you on that issue.  I have potential.  I can understand many things with proper attention and guidance.  I am not, however, SMART.  I have honestly made some of the dumbest mistakes I've ever heard of (short of what you'd see on COPS, of course...) and fail to apply rationality towards many decisions I make.  I am confounded most of the time, and, while I may think, that doesn't mean that I do it well.  

I also have a poster that my fellow members of Phi Gamma Delta made for me, listing constructive criticisms (everyone got one, and everyone commented on everyone else) now hanging on my wall.  Some of the things listed on it are laughable, simply because I seriously don't think that I quite fit the bill.  Many people have seen me fitting these actions, but I seriously think that they represent only a small fraction of me.  

This is what's on said poster:
1)Relax on weekends more
2)Come to more events
3)Don't overanalyze life
4)Conceding points shows an openness to think critically about onesself
5)Be more confident.  You're too hard on yourself.
6)Relax and enjoy life; go to more parties
7)Try increased/varied involvement outside of FIJI
8)Don't take all arguments seriously
9)(Perhaps the most interesting) Dead people's opinions shouldn't matter as much as your own thoughts and ideas, which are gained by living life, not reading about it.

Why this annoys me is that, if you'll notice, there are 4(!) references to argumentation and philosophising...  equally, there are another 4 that reference my involvement with people inside and outside of Phi Gamma Delta... The only other one tells me to boost my confidence.  From this, I appear to be 1) A recluse who doesn't like parties, 2) an argumentative sonofabitch, and 3) a person who lacks self confidence.  Now, those images together paint quite the picture...  I have to admit, I don't like that picture much, nor do I agree with it as the whole of who I am... few know my musical tastes, few know of my past, few know my distaste for books or why I am trying to make human-level artificial intelligence (indeed, nobody has asked any of these questions, either).  People are apparently content knowing only a portion of me...  I'm willing to be honest (to an extent... I'm not about to tell you about my sex life if I just met you on the street...) if you just ask. 

Anyway, I know that I've done things like this to people in the past, some of the more memorable ones being Chris and Pat...  Sorry, guys.  I'm trying to get better.  

Try explaining yourself to someone else honestly in your entirity sometime... my best is smiling, and having them live the whole of my life.  Realisitically, that ain't happening though.

-Mark

Well, my friends, I saw it.  Today, the truck, aka THE BEAST, was driven to Pekin High to be ripped apart by any car enthusiast who has a penchant for destroying things.  In a very real way, I'm sad to see it go, and it's not because I now lose my sole means of reliable transportation, but because of the memories associated with the thing.  Recalling such memories almost brings me to tears as I write this, because, as many of you know, my father died some 3 years ago, quite unexpectedly.  To see this truck go is kind of like the last nail in his coffin for me... The memories that remind me the most of my father are those of him driving that truck around to work, taking me places in it; school, fishing, to help other people move shit, etc.  I dearly love that truck as it is my last living daily reminder of my father, my last visible vestige to him...  I know that I have my memories and other petty trinkets, and most certainly, the rest of my family, but the remarkable truck that he left me was something that I always associated with him, as though his soul somehow lived on in that noble rusting form...  I swear, that thing would never die on me, regardless of how low on gas it was, it was reliable as all get out, was falling apart but still running, it's as though the thing were giving the whole of its essence to aid me, just like its previous owner had.  I'm going to miss that truck, and if you're somehow capable of reading this, I miss you too, dad.  Would have been nice to tell you  that I love you, to talk with you whenever I had troubles, have fun as you watched me grow into a real man...  There's a lot I've missed in my life, and a lot that I still have yet to remember.  I do hope that somehow, I can live up to your image in my mind, dad.  Thanks.

Mark Sheehan

Well, every time I have some sort of idea or 'revelation', I just have to put it here.  The idea to throw out there today, kiddies, is one that I've been playing with a while;  Ever since seeing Serial Experiment Lain, a fascination with some of the ideas present in it (and the people mentioned in various episodes) have led me to find out what the f*ck was meant by this anime.  After a while, something came to me.  Prevalent within the story line is the thought of the collective unconscious, and mentioned within are a few key players; Jung, Leary, and Turing.  Turing has just been interesting to investigate, as his work led to the concept of the computer, and his life was more like a fairy tale than reality... But I have been focusing more on Leary and Jung.  One of the most interesting things that I have gotten out of Lain is that one of the 'bad guys' tried to activate what Leary would call the 7th switch, gear, minibrain, etc.  This is, in the mind of Leary, the part of the brain that houses the 'collective unconscious' and allows communication through telepathy.  During Lain, the fabric between individual reality and collective unconscious reality were blurred, and something that proved to be of interest to me was the concept of having one COMPLETELY shown;  By this, I mean that the masks that we adorn ourselves with would LITERALLY be thrown off as our bodies would become things of the past, and the whole of our consciousness would be accessible to everyone;  in this situation, one couldn't hide a single thing.  For many, this would be horrible and awful, but for anyone who's studied buddhism, this experience is very much likened to nirvana, the total cessation of self and the embracement of the whole of the universe.

All that is very interesting (to me at least), but a thought occurred to me recently, and I think it is built off of the previous idea:  that the more information about others that we're exposed to, the less and less that we value or contemplate the individual;  The concept of individuality has dwindled lately, spurring many to express themselves as individuals in any way they can find.  I am reminded of the concept of 'infornography' or the desire to be flooded with information (presumably about someone, but that's my interpretation); the desire to break down the barriers between us all.  I somehow liken this to one being completly 'honest', in the sense of one not hiding themselves behind secrets and answering any question posed them when asked.  Purity of intention seems a byproduct of this. 

Will keep on thinking, kiddies, and I really do need to form my thoughts, but for the sake of not forgetting, here they are.

I write not for anyone who reads this, but instead for posterity, because, God willing, the earth will NOT be completely destroyed in twenty years and the Internet will still be alive and well so that I can access my wonderous treasure-trove of memories that is my Livejouranl.

Sarcasm aside, And not straining my brain too much (I've been doing only that lately, so I probably should be doing at least something else in its stead), I figured I'd write down some interesting connections that have popped up during the past few weeks.

1. Existentialism, Buddhism, Wu Wei:  There are some themes in these that one sees continuously in examining media nowadays (major motion pictures especially).  The one I find most often is where the budding hero 'finds himself' and liberates his will, throwing off some kind of oppressive ideology/power/giant evil computer that is trying to make him or her think like it wants him to.  Way back in the day, stories seemed to be about the standards: man vs. man, man vs. nature, man vs. metaphysical power, etc.  Now, a large focus is being put upon man vs. society and man vs. self.  Give it a thought sometime how often you see something pertaining to man following his will instead of anyone else's in this day and you, too, will be amazed.  Oh how the mindsets have shifted.

2. Forgiveness, Time, Meaning of the moment:  Thank C.S. Lewis and perhaps the many years of christian schooling, but I think I've finally gotten this forgiveness thing down.  If someone transgresses against you, the first thing that should come to your mind is 'was this an accident, will it happen again?'  If the answer is 'yes', then your efforts should be towards trying to show another why your methodology or way of thinking is right (no taking the moral high ground on this one, folks...).  If your answer is 'no', though, you should forgive such a transgression against you;  Holding a grudge when someone is genuinely sorry for their action is pointless:  What does it do besides cause more problems?  In reading Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse, another thought presented itself to me:  The past is past, the future is uncertain, and where we are is in the moment.  We can peer into the future trying to figure where it will go, but we ultimately must start working towards that future in the present, or else that idea will remain only an idea.  The idea of past goes with forgiveness, the idea of the future being nonexistant is very real, and the idea that we have to focus on what we can do to make our ideas reality makes a lot of sense.  I would say that, if you're looking for strange connections, the idea is present in Nietzsche as well...

At this point, it would be fair to state that I'm starting to have a strangely Murakami-ish feeling about these connections... for any who haven't given him a read (I recommend it, fun writing style and imaginitive worlds), one thing he'd do for 'Hard Boiled Wonderland and the End of the World' would be to have a title for a chapter that named three completely unrelated things.  Through the chapter, you would see how these seemingly unconnected items became woven into the story, all being bound by what happened to the main character.  Just something to think about.

3. Truth.  Thank you goes out to Keith Sewell who wrote an interesting paper about the nature and usage of the concept Truth.  In abbreviated form, truth is used as an independent information source.  To claim that one has found truth, one presents evidence.  The disciplines that can show consistent evidence that can be observed and understood are Science.  The disciplines that cannot are Religion.  The problem with Religion is that the basis for making a truth claim is born from something that is inherently unprovable;  be it your mystical book, dream, or startling revelation, one cannot explain clearly the reasons why one believes as they do.  As he stated, 'someone had to have initially bought the damn thing'.  For me, this coincides with my desire to understand why people think as they do.  I STILL do not understand why people accept some assumptions based off of something that, when carefully analyzed or subject to scrutiny, does not make a great deal of sense...  

4.  Desire.  We all have 'em, they're not the same within every one of us, but we have our own desires.  This will be somewhat along the lines of #1 up top, but I'm thinking now that people are unhappy whenever their natural desires (the ones they come with, inherent desires, if you will, NOT to be equated to survival instincts) go unsated, and a large reason that they go unsated is because people have been taught to accept something else in their stead:  The desires and ambitions of society, of friends, etc.  A lot of this enlightenment stuff (again with Siddhartha) appears to be a person finding what makes him happy (for some, it may be a large house and lots of money, etc. whereas for Siddhartha, he could not STAND that lifestyle) and doing it, but he has to know WHAT MAKES HIM HAPPY.  So much of this movement towards the individual has been people seeking to live their lives and fulfill their desires, and so we enjoy seeing them finding themselves and devoting their beings towards their desires once they've found 'em.  Next time you feel mopey, try and find something that is important to you, and I guarantee, you'll find the energy to do it.

5. Wasn't quite expecting a 5, but since we're here, The Ego.  Freud did a nice job of giving a visualization for its workings, and it just seems to work for me.  See below for more detail on that.  In Siddhartha, one thing that Siddhartha finds is that he needs to live his life without ego to be happy and completely sever himself from the world.  YOU EITHER CAN BE IN THE WORLD OR YOU CAN DECIDE NOT TO BE.  I throw this in because this would be number 6, except that's pretty much all it is... You decide how involved in the world of others you're going to get, and so you control how much the world affects you.  Back so Siddhartha;  So, Siddhartha finds that he can sever himself from the world all he wants (he became an ascetic and tormented himself until he could escape his self for a period of time and feel nothing...) but he had not been able to sever himself from his ego;  When he was an ascetic, he looked upon everyone else who was involved in the world as 'child-people' and thus demean them, putting himself always above them.  When he BECAME one of them, he could not stop his self-loathing because his life had become meaningless.  Once he realized that he wanted to be rid of his ego instead of the world, he then found his peace.  I am not quite sure how to go about this, I've always thought that a person's view of themselves in relation to others was somehow intertwined with their being, but, hey, what do I know.  Still and interesting idea, one that I wouldn't mind trying sometime.

7. (guess I might as well go on one more since I already did 6) - The world really does work in mysterious ways.  We DO NOT understand them all, but that does NOT mean we should STOP TRYING...  Try and learn a little Jung or perhaps some Timothy Leary, or maybe magic does exist, or Evangelion got it right with the AT Field thing(!), etc. etc. etc..  Thinking something is impossible only limits your capacity to imagine that it might be real...  If you can understand why something isn't, that's fine.  Do NOT, however, ASSUME something isn't based on something you DON'T EVEN UNDERSTAND.  I trust anyone who's reading this (including myself) to be capable of thought and rich in imagination.  Try and come up with your own all-encompassing belief system and prove how you're right.

(Andrew already got a head start with How Santa Claus is God, so Good job, Andrew!)


That's it for the rants today, hopefully, something to think about, and also, something to remember for when I'm feeling old, gray, and tired.  God knows I'm feeling that way when I'm only 21.

-Mark

Since my previous rant was interrupted (see below), I will continue the second point here:

2. There are only three ways in which a belief can be formed.

This might seem a bit out there and inconsequential, but my line of thinking is that the differences in people can be attributed to a difference of their beliefs.  This led to me asking what exactly caused such a difference in these basic beliefs, and so far, I have only come to one conclusion:  There are three ways in which a belief can be created, but it is so far unclear which of these or which combination of these is correct.  

The first way in which a belief can be formed is as an extension of desire.  Imagine, if you will, a large ball of glowing energy that represents your self (this will start to sound like Freud, and that's perfectly fine.  So far, his is the best likeness to this process that I have found).  Now, from that energy that is your self extends tendrils which represent your desires.  These desires, if unstopped, will cause you to take action to satisfy these desires.  Understand, your desires form their own form of repression of other desires (such as your desire for companionship will repress your desire for sex if you're married or your desire to eat is repressed because your desire to have enough of an appetite for a good meal overpowers it).  In this view, desires and how you sate them or repress them form your belief structure.  

The second way in which a belief can be formed is through behaviourism.  If the previous argument was the likeness of "Nature", then this one is "Nurture".  As has been said before, one could simply 'learn through blows' the right and wrong of the world as well as what to believe.  An example of this would be the person who makes a joke in a school cafeteria, recieves laughs and praise for doing so, and so continues to do so until he does not get any more chuckles from pulling such stunts or the person who believes religion primarily because it makes his parents happy that he does so.

The third method in which belief can be formed is something that has been puzzling me for a while.  The last option, as best I can tell, is through the use of 'free will'.  We decide what basic beliefs to adopt and adhere to those beliefs.  To me, this does not make sense because (and I realize this prejudice) I think that if you believe something, it has to have its causes.  The only way that this 'free will' argument for the creation of beliefs makes sense to me is if the choice is completely arbitrary in the mind of the chooser, as when one decides whether to have tuna or ham when one feels hungry, yet craves neither.  This, to me, would be the most disturbing means of all for beliefs to be formed because this would suggest that our beliefs are ARBITRARILY CHOSEN and our actions that arise because of those beliefs are founded upon beliefs that are arbitrary.  If anyone has another interpretation of free will that allows, without reliance upon the other two means, a way of forming belief, I'd be happy to hear it.  

So far, that's what I've got.  This thought is still in its infancy, and I'm trying to think about it more, but your input is welcome.  Thanks for reading (I know this is a lot, though the thoughts are relatively simple), and I hope to have given you something to think about/argue against.  Please enjoy, and have a happy holiday season-time.

-Mark

Alright, break has begun and I am thoroughly enjoying the fact that I now get about double (maybe triple!) the sleep that I did last semester.  I have been thinking on a lot of things, and as such, I'd like to impart some of the results of this thinking to provide some spark to the thinking of others.

1.  We are losing our concept of humanity.  

Let's face it, people.  With the advent of the internet, we've become infinitely more close to each other.  There was a time when we were in our own little secluded worlds and all was well and good, we could believe as we wanted, think anything we wanted abouit anyone we wanted.  Then the world got a little closer... Enter the radio.  Suddenly, we can hear the opinions and ideas of others from around the world!  Our interconnectivity jumped at that time.  Enter somewhere around 1940-50 (not sure when exactly), and the Television makes its debut.  Much like the radio, this invention connects us to our fellow men, but, unlike the radio, it does so with sight as well as sound.  The radio was practically a man speaking out of a box.  With the television, you saw the man AND you heard him speaking.  A new level of connectivity is thus reached.  Now, this leads to some interesting things:  First, we see something like the Civil Rights movement.  People had, up to this time, thought little of their fellow humans being oppressed because, while they were remotely aware of this oppression, they had not seen nor experienced it directly and in massive quantity.  The television and literature of the time now bring this issue into focus, as people see other people bombarded by water cannons, attacked by trained killing dogs, and beaten mercilessly by policemen.  This is a bit of a shock to a person, because, after seeing such an event, you CANNOT deny that such things are happening without being delusional.  As a result of this media attention, many people's minds were swayed towards the suffering of their fellow humans (if one thought about it, there was little to seperate the black man from the white one, either mentally or physically, though that didn't stop some people from trying to find such differences).  Thus, on a national scale, we see a movement towards respecting one's fellow human beings, and a good deal of that is thanks to this new interconnectivity breaking through the apathy of years gone by.  Flash forward a few years to the Vietnam War.  Few knew what was really going on over there, and, frankly, few cared.  We were merely fighting another war, just cause or not, and our soldiers were fighting and doing their duty.  Enter the media again.  People were happily living their lives inside a bubble, thinking that nothing too bad was going on over in Vietnam until journalists and cameramen went over and brought back real footage and a persistent body count.  The sheer loss of life and anguish on the battlefield was enough to shock people out of their dormant existence and cause them to realize that war isn't great, grand, or nice.  As the body count soared, people began questioning the motives for the war;  After all, if you're spending so many American lives on a project that doesn't seem right in the first place, somebody's got some explaining to do.  People demanded either a GOOD reason for the war (in their eyes, mind you... fighting to keep some Vietnamese independent was a little too far out of the scope of most, which only serves to show that apathy for others around the world had already set in, but I'll get to that later) or that the suffering of American soldiers be ended and that the soldiers be brought home.  This sense of connectiveness brought about by the newscrews over in Vietnam grasped the American public and wrenched them from their simple lives and forced them to realize how brutal the war was, how REAL the war was.  After that, we saw a movement towards humanity again as many fought against the government to 'bring the boys home'.  The soldiers were only young Americans, after all, with their own lives to live and their own hopes, dreams, and desires.  These were people being put into harms way, and the reasoning behind this was insufficient to warrant the risk. Many such examples can be seen in modern history where a people are completely apathetic about something until they become fully aware of what is going on, until they are exposed enough to an event to become empathetic to the people being oppressed/sent into danger/persecuted, what have you.

So, this brings me to the thought that because of our vast interconnectivity, we've become less and less empathetic towards each other.  

With the dawning of such great interconnectivity in time, we have continually been exposed to more and more people.  With the advent of cities and suburbs, we've become exposed to more people than in the days of vast country and farmland everywhere.  This exposure to so many people has caused a DEvaluation of people in general in our lives.  Think about this:  How many people do you pass each day while walking around that you wouldn't even give a second thought to?  You realize (and perhaps say to yourself) that they're people, but you do not even try to get to know them.  They BECOME stereotypes, generalizations, simple mockeries of themselves, all because you don't have the time to get to know each one individually beyond their stereotype.  What I am saying here is that we are assaulted with so much information, exposed to so many people in our day to day workings that we HAVE to stereotype, else we'd get overloaded on information (and not get too much done).  Here's a thought exercise.  If you were trapped on an island with one person, would you get to know them?  Would your desire for human contact drive you towards that person even if they're a jerk, someone completely unlike you, etc., and would they in turn not be driven towards you?  Would you AT LEAST get to know this person well enough to say "I genuinely don't like this guy and would rather spend my time alone than with him" ?  I say that we would.  Now, imagine yourself alone on an island with two people.  Same outcome, right?  How about five, ten, twenty, two-hundred?  The higher we go up in number, the more we realize that we begin to shrug off our feeling of sympathy and empathy towards one another, that we instead form close friends and leave everyone else out of our little circle.  The problem with this is that 200 people is maybe a small community, and we could agree that you might get to know each person in great detail if exposed to them enough times, but imagine something like a city, a nation, or perhaps, the world...  You're suddenly looking at 1000+ people that you're NOT going to get to know well.  You DO NOT feel connected to this large mass of people because you don't know many of them (nor is it really possible to get to know many of them).  So, what do you do?  You stereotype.  You also do something else;  A desire we all have is to be a part of something, to feel connected to something, so we find ourselves a group of people like ourselves and we try to fit in.  In our desire to have friends and fit into something greater than ourselves, we ultimately form a basis for others to stereotype us as.  If you're a "churchie", for example, you go to church all the time, you stay with the people from your church, you define yourself by that relationship, and that is precisely how others will define you as well.  In your desire to feel connected to a group, you find your group, be yourself (for the most part), and enable others to form a blanket stereotype of you.  

Admittedly, this is interesting, but this leads towards another point:  Since we all form stereotypes of each other outside of our own tiny group of friends, we BEGIN TO SEE OTHERS AS LESS THAN HUMAN.  

This will seem an odd comment, but if you consider whether you value your friends more highly than you do any other human, you're devaluing the rest of humanity.  If you were the CEO of a company and your close friends were working under you, would you pull some scam to make millions but leave your friends in the dirt?  If your friends were being governed by you, would you accept bribes and oppress them?  The point I'm making is this:  We, being exposed to so many people, have lost our sense of sympathy and our ability to put ourselves in others' positions.  Apathy has overcome us all, and we're not even trying to break free.  Only when someone comes up with something so shocking that it chills us to the bone do we even consider that maybe, MAYBE we should have done something different.  

My last tidbit of advice is to Be aware of what you do.  Think about others and how they think about you, and maybe, just maybe, you can change the world.

**********************************************************************************************************

Have fun.

Well, I've been at this a few minutes, and it appears that it's evolved from a simple poem to someting a small bit grander... I'm actually going through what I can envision and figure a couple of different views about life and what it means... interesting concept, that...

Human, too human after all...

questions for a meandering mind:

What does it mean to be human?  
Is it something quite trivial or grand?
is it simple, or hardened, or yellow or purple,
is it as solid on the ground which you stand?

What does it mean to be human? 
We're all only human after all...
so what does it mean to be caught at the scene
breaking this unscribed and far-fetched law?

What does it mean to be human? 
perhaps it is something that only time can tell?
perhaps meant to be shrouded behind the mists of our minds,
protected from prying by untouchable shell.

What does it mean to be human?
A sleight of fate and a twist of hand?
A nonsensical ride throughout the land?
a tortured plight which none can stand,
A place without answers yet not lacking demand?

What does it mean to be human? 
A view for a vagabond, a spectacle of spectacles,
each of us crafting our own,
but whatever light we see through our eyes,
reflects only a shard of what's shown?

The answers that present:

So, what does it mean to be human?
To fight bravely for our cause!
to enjoy the battle, and when the day is won,
to carry on without a pause!

So, what does it mean to be human?
To wither and waste away...
to spend our lives seeing others die,
and callously languish the day...

So, what does it mean to be human?
A sacrifice, life given of self, 
A living of life towards God,
in that lies a true life's wealth.

So, what does it mean to be human?
The pursuit of that which men value
is only what interests me,
without businessman, briefcase, and banknote, 
what other life could there be?



Wow, that really could use some amount of development, but I rather like where it's going...  The concept of trying to understand why people believe as they do still amazes me... I'm still trying to understand it all.

People find meaning to life.  Do you find meaning in meaning?

The world is still a very creepy scary funny fantastic place, and I, while having my very rough moments, am thoroughly enjoying myself.  

Oh, and existentialism is a fun class.  Gotta love the mentality. Neat thoughts too...

I'm also considering starting on something that felt quite strange yet necessary;  something much akin to Thus Spoke Zarathustra, but voicing the opinion of a boisterous fellow who isn't nearly as laid back as Z.  This fellow is a Nihilist in the darkest sense of the word;  He's out to destroy, and only destroy.  A madman kamikaze suicide bomber of thought... just sounded fun to me, and would certainly be a hoot to write.  Character would be named Ezekiel, methinks.

Anyway, share thoughts/comments/life/anything with me, and don't be afraid to add to that poem thingamabobber I started with some view of your own.

"I am the cannon, my word is the shell.  You can either rebuild as I destroy your foundations, or feign ignorance as the shots whistle past your head!"
-Ezekiel

Story of the World

	I walked solemnly up the brick path to the small house, marvelling as I went past at the diverse foliage surrounding the place.  Most greenery was kept in small domes interspersed in public parks through the dense, cold cities, defiantly contrasting, but invariably bound to, the cold glass, concrete and steel all around them.  The plants around here were growing calmly, unhindered by regulators, trimming mechanisms, or anything else that would stop them from growing wild and unkempt;  to me, this wild vegitative haven was beautiful.
	As I approached the house, I was confronted with a simple wooden gate;  I was amazed by this, so little real wood existed outside of the parks that to see some employed elsewhere left me awestruck.  I pushed aside this small bit of amazement and continued up the path towards the house;  This too seemed a little out of place, as the world was covered with large skyscraper apartments, each invariably looking like the others around it.  This house was small, only a single floor, and it was ornately decorated outside, adding to the air of oddity around this place.  "Such an inefficient use of space," somewhere deep in my mind told me, but I ignored it like I always have.  Wandering up the steps, I was met with a quaint white door with a single window and an intricate brass handle, another far cry from the other parts of the City where lifeless steel intelli-doors greet you coldly wherever you travel.  Mustering up my courage, I pressed the doorbell and waited.  After a few seconds, a shuffling of feet echoed through the door, and an almost pained grunt signaled that someone was coming to answer my call.  The door creaked open slowly ("strange," I thought, "that there was no lock, for surely I would have heard it.").  A wrinkled face greeted me, the face of the man I had come to see.  
	"Who are you, and what do you want?" asked the wrinkled figure through the crack in the doorway.  Carefully and cautiously, for I had practiced this many times before, I replied:  
	"Who I am matters not, but I come here with great reason;  I yearn for answers to questions."
	"What do you seek, good stranger, in regard to your questions?"
	At this, I became noticeably nervous;  I had been told to expect the first question, but had not been wanred about a second. 
I began fumbling for answers. Eventually, I accepted that I could only be honest from there on in, and hoped that my answers would carry me.  "I seek Truth, and simply that."
	The old man's eyes took on a look of suspicion, and with a voice shrill and cold, he said "If you seek entertainment, I can dance and sing and tell stories until the sun has set and risen a hundred times.  If you seek enlightenment, perhaps I can help you along the path, playing the role of both guide and tutor aiming towards peace and happiness.  But if it is Truth you seek, then I'm afraid you've come to the wrong place."  
	At this, he began to close the door.  I quickly began to speak, pleading with him to allow me entrance.  "You once searched for Truth, and I have now undertaken the same journey.  Please allow me to learn what you know, what you've experienced throughout your life;  I don't want bastardizations, I don't want hype and misinformation, I just want to know what you really think!"
	His brow curled even more, but his voice betrayed a certain hint of curiosity.  "What does it matter what I think, young one?"
	I thought for a second, and simply replied, "What you said and did changed the world, but so many have failed to realize it and have forgotten about you.  I only try to understand why you thought, said, and did what you did."
	A wry smile creeped over his face at my utterance, and he asked, "and what good will this information do you, young stranger?"
 	I again had to stop and think.  "It will do me little good beyond satisfying my curiosity and perhaps aiding my journey with another perspective to view the world with."  I had answered honestly, and I hoped he would accept my humble plea.

Well, I recently went to see the Andrew Lloyd Weber play, Cats.  Now, I have seen it before, heard it MANY times at home (someone in our family really liked the music), and have watched it on TV.  It NEVER occured to me to listen to the lyrics and think about it.  HOLY CRAP!  The play is fun to watch and the music is very catchy (and you have to love some of the characters) but I think I had a bit of a trash-can revelation while thinking about some of the lyrics;  I took notes at the performance (decided to have a little fun and the program came with a notes section... what kind of production does that!?!) and made a couple of interesting connections.  This stuff is rather obvious, so I'm not patting myself on the back too much, but it has given me something to think about.  

1) The Jellicle(?) cats have 3 names:  Their home name, their fancy proper name, and their individual name that is unlike any other's.

One can equate this to humans;  We have our birth name, what everyone knows us by, then we have formal titles like doctor, professor, etc., still accepted, and then we have our own individual name unlike anyone else's... To me, this is our selves, the special combination of thoughts, actions, experiences that make us us.  There will only be one us, and that us may very well never be known to anyone but ourselves.

2) The frequent mention of the meaning of what happiness is and reincarnation (living another life).

 Well, I haven't completely figured it out yet, but the connection made in the play was that once one knows what the meaning of happiness is, he can start life anew.  Methinks this means that once has found happiness and their means of attaining it, they can begin life frequented by happiness instead of misery longing for fleeting moments of happiness that one had in times gone by.  More on this later:

3) A crack by the Theatre-cat about the young'uns being able to jump through hoops and patting themselves on the back about it

I had to laugh at this (no one else did), primarily because it's quite the true observation;  (warning, rant ahead) We as a people are beginning to think that because we are capable of earning degrees and learning methodologies (thus the jumping through hoops) we are some kind of great beings;  My friends, I think that it is not method but means of figuring one's way there that makes one great.  Of course I'm using borrowed words, but curiosity is better than knowledge.  

4) The concept of MaCavity (he's a mischievious cat who does bad things) intrigues me;  As his song suggests, he was never at the scene of the crime which could mean he was fleet of foot to get out or that *he never actually was there*.  Everything bad always happened, no-one saw macavity do it, so I began wondering if he was perhaps an explanation of random causality  (blame it on the cat, so to speak).  Also, if Macavity did in fact not exist, then he was merely an explanation of all the bad that happened around;  He became the embodiment of evil, much like the christian concept of the devil.  Or, he was just a sly cat who did bad things.  That's likely the case.

5) During the moving song Memory, it appears as though happiness is explained (Touch me and see what happiness is!) as lending a helping hand out to those who are downtrodden and despised;  The cat who sings Memory used to be beautiful, now she's ugly and despised.  I'm wondering if Weber's interpretation of this is that people need to help each other out, relieving our continual loneliness and pulling us out of our ignorant misery and self-hate.  Think about that sometime.  Love=happiness?  Helping others achieve and bloom like self-made seeds, breaking out of their shells to enjoy the wonderful sunlight that they've been hiding themselves from all the years.

Finally, 

It appears that cats are NOT dogs (an odd lyrics, but one that really hits home).  Cats, in this sense, are really People.  We are all quite diverse in our mentalities and personalities, but we all deserve respect until proven otherwise (I don't hate him because he's another skin-tone.  I hate him because he's an asshole!).  This play has alerted me to an interesting thought (trashcan revelation) that people are diverse and interesting (each cat could have had an entire play written about its life).  One can assume things about people by looking at them (rum tum tugger comes to mind), but, love them or hate them, you can only really love or hate the characters when they explain themselves to you!  Check out the last song to see what I'm saying. 

Listen carefully and you'll see that Andrew Lloyd Weber's play actually has some interesting philosophical thoughts.  Keep on thikning, kiddies!

Well, for my own amusement, I got around to trying to think in the vein of Rationalists (egged on by a section in Sophie's World describing the great differences of opinion between Parminedes and Hericlitus).

First, Rationalists (to my understanding) are people who believe that the rationalizations of the mind are what is real and that perception has a nasty tendancy to give misinformation.  I used this as my basis for a fundamental thought experiment that had a funny outcome in, oh, 6 easy steps or so.

Here goes, kiddies (thought up while waiting in line at Taco Bell after a good day's work):

First thought:  I think, therefore I am.  
The most basic of principles, if I am capable of pondering my existence, I exist in some way/shape/form.  It is interesting to note that this appears to be where the concept of respect for the 'other' comes from;  Our only way of judging that which is 'real' in this world is that it is capable of thought (We are, we exist).  Since 'others' are capable of thought as well, they should be respected for that ability and their existence.

Second Thought:  The World around us is Real
Well, I know I'm usually a proponent of us all being tied in a machine somewhere running computer programs in our sleep, but rationally, this one makes sense.  According to our sense data (relying on perception...), our world  has existed and will continue to exist independent of us, in other words, it is consistently real.  Admittedly, this could be a delusion, but for all intensive purposes, if it looks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's reality, folks.  (Take that, solipism!)

Third Thought:  The World around us is bound by rules
It's not hard, folks.  Our world is one of grand cause and effect.  If we do something, there is invariably a rule behind it governing what effect it will have.  Science is us trying to figure out these rules.  It is, as I am wont to say, very much like a game.

Fourth Thought:  God is claimed to be the Cause of the World
Now, here the trainwreck arrives, my friends...  Either we've made a mistake beforehand (Our second thought is incorrect in assuming this world is real or our third thought is erred in that we think that all things have a governing cause) or God cannot be the end all be all as claimed by so many... Interestingly enough, many have asked the question of where God came from, and it is amusing to envision God willing himself into existence... But the problem still stands;  The very notion of God as root cause (nothing above him) appears erroneous.  However, an interesting dillemma of equal proportion arises in asking where the laws governing the universe that we know of (namely physics, mathematics, chemistry, biology, etc.) came from, what their cause was.  

All in all, that's about as far as I got before my food arrived.  It was very tasty.  Surprisingly fun time, trying to think from someone else's perspective.

I now stood outside of a modest hovel on the outskirts of town, eyeing the quaint well-kept bushes that ensnared the simple brick structure.  The windows were smudged and dirty and I could not see anything inside, but I could tell this was where he lived.  Holding back my elation and swallowing my pride, I pushed the tiny ornamental gate open and followed the welcoming path up to the front door.  The gate creaked as I passed, slipping into its past position, and I admired the breadth and beauty of the garden that overwhelmed the front yard.  I was getting lost in gardenias, remniscing in the roses, and before I knew it, had made it up the wooden stairs onto the porch, standing squarely in front of the door.  With an audible gulp, I pushed the doorbell, hearing a quaint chime emenating from the other side of the door.  I heard footsteps and my heart jumped.  I had waited for this moment for so long, and I cradled my surprise in the pocket of my jacket.  I thought it funny that this man had deserved this, all these years, and here I was, ready to give it to him.  A creaking of the handle almost made me jump;  I was so nervous that sweat was beading upon my brow.  My breathing was irregular and heavy, and as the door creaked open, I pulled the object out of my coat pocket, hiding it behind my back.  "Hello," I began, spying the wrinkled eyes that I remembere so well hiding behind thick spectacles.  "I''ve been looking for you for many long years now," my eyes flaring and coming to bright life as my excitement overtook me, "and here you are.  I'm sure you know why I'm here... I'm hoping to repay you for what you did to me fifteen years ago."  A sly smile creeped across my lips.  With the completion of this statement, I pulled the object from behind me quickly, noting a startled look on the old man's face, his mouth suddenly agape.  "Here you go!"  

He outstretched his frail arm, taking the trinket from me.  It was nothing more than a simple bauble, really, merely a jewel encrusted broach whose monetary value was nonexistant, but the man smiled upon recieving it,  knowing full well its true value;  his eyes welled up with tears, and I mused that it was not unlike looking into two overflowing fishbowls when peering into his eyes.  The broach, as he knew, had belonged to my mother and was the last thing that I had to remember her by.  "I wanted to thank you for saving my life earlier.  Without your help, I surely would have died.  I never asked to be saved and in fact had not wanted to be, yet you still did.  I cannot say that this life that was given to me has always been pleasant, but I can tell you that it has been quite the experience. After you saved me, I had to think about why you had done so... certainly you had gained nothing as a result, but instead gave of yourself to help me.  I concluded that this could only have been a genuine act of love, to give me back my life.  I wanted to let you know that I have been helping others as you have helped me, I am that thankful for your intervention.  I wanted you to know how much love I have shown humanity because of the love you have shown me.  I will continue to devote myself to helping others with their predicaments, helping save them from their own problems, but I primarily wanted to simply say 'thank you'."  With this, he reached forward and hugged me, a warm embrace that I have never felt before or since, rubbing his watered cheeks into my jacket.  I smiled and he, looking up, returned it.  His embrace loosened, and I waved a silent goodbye to his joyful form.  I turned and walked away, ready to continue in my servitude of this grand love that this man had shown me. 

I was truly happy as I walked away, spying another person wandering the street carefully examining the housenumbers, an excited expression on his face, his right hand shielding some treasure.  I looked at him and smiled, saying simply, "Third house on the left."

well, it all began humbly enough, born as a child through normal means, cared for and loved, told I was good, much as any child should be.  I grew up, a bright young kid, showing a lot of promise, very creative, good with numbers, a quick learner.  Then I began to slack off.  I know not why, but I did.  I knew that sooner or later I would have to work, to bear the yoke of adulthood, to become responsible.  I spent my days as if Peter Pan in some wonderful world where I needn't grow up.  In all of that time, I have learned to favor my own whims when it comes to my actions instead of considering those others who cheer me on from the sidelines.  My mother, for instance, is paying about 6k a semester at the moment to send me to a good college for engineering.  I have made friends, and I have learned much, but as for the effort I have exerted, I definately know I could give much, much more.  I lack the willpower to force myself to learn, instead giving in to my own worldy pleasures.  I have lost my sense of dignity, for in cleaning up my room today, I found many momentos of the people who care about me and want to see me succeed.  I do not need to do this for myself, for I would be happy as a manual laborer, but for the people who support me.  For you guys, I will give this one more try, or else I will quit college for now, in order to allow myself to mature.  Good bye, dream, hello reality.
